entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Louisiana...
Bodcau Bayou At Bayou Bodcau Lake affecting Webster and Bossier Parishes.
For the Bodcau Bayou...including Bayou Bodcau Lake...Minor flooding is forecast.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Bodcau Bayou at Bayou Bodcau Lake.
* WHEN...Until early Monday afternoon.
* IMPACTS...At 172.0 feet, Expect bankfull conditions on Red Chute Bayou.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 12:00 PM CST Thursday the stage was 173.4 feet. - Bankfull stage is 171.0 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 12:00 PM CST Thursday was 173.9 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to fall below flood stage Sunday evening and continue falling to 171.5 feet Tuesday morning. - Flood stage is 172.0 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 173.4 feet on 05/09/1970. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued March 7 at 1:30PM EST by NWS Miami FL
entry.summary:
At 129 PM EST, National Weather Service meteorologists were tracking a strong thunderstorm capable of producing a funnel cloud over Rotenberger Wildlife Refuge, or 19 miles south of Lake Harbor, moving east at 15 mph.
HAZARD...Funnel clouds and winds in excess of 40 mph.
SOURCE...Radar indicated.
IMPACT...Funnel clouds occasionally touch down and produce tornadoes or waterspouts. Gusty winds could knock down tree limbs and blow around unsecured objects.
Locations impacted include... Okeelanta, Holey Land Wildlife Refuge, Big Cypress Seminole Reservation, Rotenberger Wildlife Refuge, Miccosukee Indian Reservation, Miccosukee Service Plaza, Big Cypress National Preserve, and West Broward Rec. Area On Alligator Alley.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Hendry; Inland Palm Beach County; Inland Collier County; Inland Broward County

cap:parameter.value: A strong thunderstorm will impact portions of east central Collier, southeastern Hendry, northern Broward and southwestern Palm Beach Counties through 200 PM EST

entry.title: Flood Watch issued March 7 at 1:27PM EST until March 10 at 1:00AM EST by NWS Peachtree City GA
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Flash flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues to be possible.
* WHERE...A portion of east central Georgia, including the following counties, Glascock, Jefferson, Warren and Washington.
* WHEN...From Friday evening through late Saturday night.
* IMPACTS...Excessive runoff may result in flooding of rivers, creeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations. Area creeks and streams are running high and could flood with more heavy rain.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - A storm system will produce moderate to heavy rainfall in the region between Friday night and Saturday night. Rainfall totals of 2 to 4 inches are expected, with locally high amounts possible. This rainfall combined with saturated soil conditions will likely produce flooding. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Flood Watch issued March 7 at 12:17PM CST until March 9 at 3:00PM CST by NWS Birmingham AL
entry.summary:
Heavy rainfall that may lead to flash flooding is expected to arrive as early as midday Friday and may persist through Saturday afternoon. Rainfall amounts of 2 to 4 inches with locally higher amounts are likely. Heavy rainfall that occurs is expected to rapidly run off due to fairly wet soil conditions currently in place across central Alabama. Flash flooding will be possible as a result, along with rises on small streams and drainage basins.
* WHAT...Flash flooding caused by excessive rainfall continues to be possible.
* WHERE...A portion of central Alabama, including the following counties, Autauga, Barbour, Bibb, Blount, Bullock, Calhoun, Chambers, Cherokee, Chilton, Clay, Cleburne, Coosa, Dallas, Elmore, Etowah, Fayette, Greene, Hale, Jefferson, Lamar, Lee, Lowndes, Macon, Marengo, Marion, Montgomery, Perry, Pickens, Pike, Randolph, Russell, Shelby, St. Clair, Sumter, Talladega, Tallapoosa, Tuscaloosa, Walker and Winston.
* WHEN...From Friday afternoon through Saturday afternoon.
* IMPACTS...Excessive runoff may result in flooding of rivers, creeks, streams, and other low-lying and flood-prone locations. Flooding may occur in poor drainage and urban areas.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: High Surf Advisory issued March 8 at 3:13AM ChST until March 11 at 3:00PM ChST by NWS Tiyan GU
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Large breaking waves of 9 to 11 feet.
* WHERE...East facing reefs of Kosrae.
* WHEN...Until 3 PM ChST Monday.
* IMPACTS...Dangerous swimming and surfing conditions and localized beach erosion.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Surf is being supported by a large trade-wind surge that extends eastward to Hawaii. This will keep surf high along east facing reefs through at least Monday afternoon.

entry.title: Coastal Flood Statement issued March 8 at 3:13AM ChST until March 11 at 3:00PM ChST by NWS Tiyan GU
entry.summary:
* WHAT...For the High Surf Advisory, Large breaking waves of 10 to 12 feet, building to 13 feet over the weekend. For the Coastal Flood Statement, isolated minor coastal flooding expected.
* WHERE...North and east facing reefs of Majuro.
* WHEN...For the High Surf Advisory, until 3 PM ChST Monday. For the Coastal Flood Statement, from this afternoon through Monday afternoon.
* IMPACTS...Some water on low lying roads and property. Dangerous swimming and surfing conditions and localized beach erosion.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Surf is being supported by a large trade-wind surge that extends eastward to Hawaii. With the upcoming King Tides around March 10th, minor coastal inundation is expected starting this afternoon, especially during high tide. Greatest risk will be along shores exposed to the northeast to east across the Marshall Islands since surf and tides will be higher around the Marshall Islands. Please report any inundation to the local Weather Service Office (WSO).

cap:parameter.value: HIGH SURF ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 3 PM CHST MONDAY... ...COASTAL FLOOD STATEMENT IN EFFECT FROM THIS AFTERNOON THROUGH MONDAY AFTERNOON

entry.title: Fire Weather Watch issued March 7 at 10:49AM CST until March 8 at 4:00PM CST by NWS Brownsville TX
entry.summary:
...A FIRE WEATHER WATCH IS IN EFFECT FRIDAY LATE MORNING AND AFTERNOON FOR LOCATIONS ALONG AND WEST OF INTERSTATE HIGHWAY 69C...
.A dry cold front ushers in rapidly lowering relative humidity and moderate to gusty winds elevating the fire danger for potential rapid growth and spread of any wildfires that may get started.
The National Weather Service in Brownsville has issued a Fire Weather Watch for Zapata, Jim Hogg, Brooks, Starr, and Hidalgo Counties, which is in effect from late Friday morning through Friday afternoon.
* AFFECTED AREA...Fire Weather Zone 248 Zapata, Fire Weather Zone 249 Jim Hogg, Fire Weather Zone 250 Brooks, Fire Weather Zone 252 Starr, Fire Weather Zone 253 Southern Hidalgo and Fire Weather Zone 353 Northern Hidalgo.
* TIMING...11 AM CST to 4 PM CST.
* WINDS...North to northwest 15 to 20 mph with gusts up to 30 mph.
* RELATIVE HUMIDITY...As low as 15 percent.
* TEMPERATURES...Up to 88.
*LIGHTNING...NONE.
* IMPACTS...Rapid spread of wildfire on drying grasses and brush is possibly Friday.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Zapata; Jim Hogg; Brooks; Starr; Southern Hidalgo; Northern Hidalgo

entry.summary:
* WHAT...Large breaking waves of 4 to 7 feet. Dangerous rip currents expected. Minor tidal overflows possible Friday morning.
* WHERE...Santa Barbara County Southwestern Coast and Santa Barbara County Southeastern Coast. Surf highest of west facing shores. Minor tidal overflows onto parking lots and normally dry beach walkways are possible with the high tide between 6AM and 9AM Friday.
* WHEN...Until 8 AM PST Friday.
* IMPACTS...There is an increased risk for ocean drowning. Rip currents can pull swimmers and surfers out to sea. Large breaking waves can cause injury, wash people off beaches and rocks, and capsize small boats near shore.

entry.title: Winter Storm Warning issued March 7 at 9:17AM MST until March 8 at 5:00AM MST by NWS Goodland KS
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Heavy wet snow and mixed precipitation expected. Total snow accumulations of 2 to 8 inches and ice accumulations of a light glaze.
* WHERE...Yuma County.
* WHEN...Until 5 AM MST Friday.
* IMPACTS...Plan on slippery road conditions. The hazardous conditions could impact the morning or evening commute.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...A band of heavy wet snow is forecast to develop mainly along and north of Highway 36 in Yuma County around 9am and persist through the late afternoon hours. Snowfall rates of 2-3 inches per hour are possible in this area. Snowfall amounts may locally approach 10 inches; especially in northern portions of Yuma county. A significant snowfall gradient may exist across the county, with the highest favoring the north. A period of freezing rain and sleet is possible around sunrise as cooler air moves in and changes rain into wintry precipitation.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued March 7 at 3:17AM AKST by NWS Fairbanks AK
entry.summary:
A deep arctic trough will move south over the Western Interior and West Coast and bring well below normal temperatures beginning Friday night. High pressure over the Chukchi Sea will bring strong north winds starting Friday night as well. Low temperatures by Saturday morning will be in the teens and 20s below zero and remain that way through Wednesday morning. Highs will range from near zero to 10 below. North winds of 10 to 30 mph with higher gusts will bring wind chills as low as the 40s to near 50 below zero.
Residents and those traveling in the area are encouraged to be prepared for much colder than normal conditions.
entry.cap:areaDesc: South Slopes of the Western Brooks Range; Noatak Valley; Kivalina and Red Dog Dock; Lower Kobuk Valley; Baldwin Peninsula; Northern Seward Peninsula; Upper Kobuk Valleys; Shishmaref; Bering Strait Coast; Southern Seward Peninsula Coast; Interior Seward Peninsula; Eastern Norton Sound and Nulato Hills; Yukon Delta Coast; Lower Yukon River; St Lawrence Island; Lower Koyukuk Valley; Middle Yukon Valley; Lower Yukon and Innoko Valleys

entry.title: Hydrologic Outlook issued March 6 at 3:01PM CST by NWS Bismarck ND
entry.summary:
ESFBIS
Given the recent cold weather, the Missouri River has again been forming ice below Garrison Dam. Thus far, ice has filled the recently cleared portion of the Missouri River from roughly Apple Creek Wildlife Management Area to about three-fourths of a mile upstream of where 12th street southeast turns into Oahe Bend. This would roughly be equal to a little less than five miles of new ice in the river.
The upstream edge of immobile ice as of Wednesday morning was roughly three and a half miles downstream of Fort Abraham Lincoln and Fox Island. While the future rate of ice formation is difficult to predict, forecast overnight lows in the single digits for both Thursday and Friday mornings will continue to encourage ice formation. It should be expected that the upstream edge of continuous ice on the river will migrate upstream. Based on how much ice has already been put in place, it is possible that the upstream edge of continuous ice will reach the Fox Island area before warmer weather enters the area on Friday. By late Saturday, warmer weather will once again reverse this process and start removing ice.
Importantly, pre-ice river levels were about 3.5 feet below that observed prior to last week's ice jam due to already planned lower releases out of Garrison Dam. This suggests that a return to water levels experienced in late February is not likely.

cap:parameter.value: MISSOURI RIVER IS ONCE AGAIN MAKING ICE
